factoid: Ilágin said, "Once she had missed it and turned it away, any mongrel could take it."
Ilágin was breathless from his gallop and excitement.
Natásha screamed joyously, ecstatically, and piercingly at the same moment.
Natásha's shriek set everyone's ears tingling.
Natásha's shriek expressed what the others expressed by all talking at once.
Natásha might have been ashamed of her wild cry.
Everyone else would have been amazed by Natásha's cry at any other time.
Uncle twisted up the hare.
Uncle threw the hare neatly and smartly across his horse's back.
Uncle's gesture was meant to rebuke everybody.
Uncle had an air of not wishing to speak to anyone.
Uncle mounted his bay and rode off.
The others followed Uncle, dispirited and shamefaced.
The others later regained their former affectation of indifference.
The others looked at red Rugáy for a long time.
red Rugáy had an arched back spattered with mud.
red Rugáy had a ring of his leash clanking.
red Rugáy walked just behind Uncle's horse.
red Rugáy had a serene air of a conqueror.
Uncle said, "Well, I am like any other dog as long as it’s not a question of coursing. But when it is, then look out!"
Uncle's appearance seemed to Nicholas to be saying the above.
Nicholas felt flattered after Uncle rode up to him and began talking to him.
Nicholas felt flattered that Uncle deigned to speak to him.
Ilágin took leave of Nicholas.
Nicholas found that they were far from home.
Nicholas accepted Uncle's offer that the hunting party should spend the night in Uncle's little village of Mikháylovna.
Uncle said, "And if you put up at my house that will be better still. That’s it, come on!"
Uncle said, "You see it’s damp weather, and you could rest, and the little countess could be driven home in a trap."
Uncle's offer was accepted.
A huntsman was sent to Otrádnoe for a trap.
Nicholas rode with Natásha and Pétya to Uncle's house.
Five male domestic serfs rushed out to the front porch to meet their master.
A score of women serfs, old and young, and children popped out from the back entrance to look at the hunters arriving.
Natásha was a woman, a lady, and on horseback.
The presence of Natásha raised the curiosity of the serfs.
Many serfs came up to Natásha.
Many serfs stared at Natásha in the face.
Many serfs made remarks about Natásha as though she were a prodigy on show.
Many serfs made remarks about Natásha as though she were not a human being able to hear or understand what was said about her.
Someone shouted, "Arínka! Look, she sits sideways!"
Someone shouted, "There she sits and her skirt dangles."
Someone shouted, "See, she’s got a little hunting horn!"
Someone shouted, "Goodness gracious! See her knife?"
Someone shouted, "Isn’t she a Tartar!"
Someone asked, "How is it you didn’t go head over heels?" addressing Natásha directly.
Uncle dismounted at the porch of his little wooden house.
The porch was in the midst of an overgrown garden.
Uncle glanced at his retainer.
Uncle shouted authoritatively that the superfluous ones should take themselves off.
Uncle shouted authoritatively that all necessary preparations should be made to receive the guests and the visitors.
The serfs dispersed.
Uncle lifted Natásha off her horse.
Uncle took Natásha's hand.
Uncle led Natásha up the rickety wooden steps of the porch.
The house had bare, unplastered log walls.
The house was not overclean.
Those living in the house did not aim at keeping it spotless.
The house was not noticeably neglected.
In the entry there was a smell of fresh apples.
Wolf skins hung about in the entry.
Fox skins hung about in the entry.
